Final Fantasy is back. Again. For the 3rd time. But what's nice is this game is fully optimized to play on new hardware. I won't go into specifics on what Final Fantasy VII is all about, since unless you have been living under a rock, you already know. But for those rock dwellers, I will give some basics. Final Fantasy VII is an epic turn based RPG. One of the finest in its genre. It has a grand story. Memorable characters. An amazing soundtrack. Everything has aged wonderfully, except I'd say the visuals. Luckily with the power of the MOD, you can relive this classic with a fresh spin of the visuals (just search around) giving you a new experience on this gem. The only problem with modding FFVII is that you will need to roll back the exe which will in turn disable any achievements. So I'd suggest for achievement hunters that you play through the game unmodded. And replay it later with the beautiful mods added.   With that said, aside from better new system support, this re-release of FFVII also adds a higher res for the included character designs, as well as cloud saving, and a mode which will increase HP and Gil, with a seemingly tedious process. The latter mode is completely optional, but works in a way which does not hamper any enemy level scaling. It only boosts HP/MP, and not any stats or levels. So you will get the same scaling flow you would when playing it normally. This however does mess with your limit meter. So use at your own risk.    either way, FFVII is a great classic. Fans of it originally should check out this re-release. And newcomers need to experience this at least once in their lives.

Final Fantasy VII is one of those games that everyone knows. It was revolutionary when it first came out for the PS1, and was one of the best selling games of 1997. The PC port is amazing. The original soundtrack was replaced with a newer soundtrack, and the graphics were also dramatically improved. I, personally, did not enjoy the music that was put into the PC port of this. However, with the aid of mods, I was able to replace the PC soundtrack with the classic PS1 soundtrack. The PC port also offers 3 different graphics choices, depending on the preferences of the user. The user can choose between the PS1 graphics, or the PC graphics, as well as a mod that gives combat 3D graphics. One downside of this game, is the fact that you have to create a Square Enix account to play. This was a disappointment for me, but not enough to keep me from playing it. Aside from the technical aspects of this game, the gameplay is amazing. This is by far, the best game I have ever owned, because of the great story, the great soundtrack, the amazing combat, and the replayability. After spending over 500 hours on this game over three different game systems, I won't be stopping any time soon. I highly recommend FFVII, and honestly, this game is worth much more than $11.99.

Final Fantasy VII is the first game I played on the original PSX back in 97. I was 10 at the time and the most advanced game I'd played until that point was Sonic ;) FFVII opened up an entire new world for me, showing what video games can and should be. With a story better than any film, that is both tragic and at times wonderfully frivolous and off the wall, the emotional dynamism of this game makes it an all time classic. It changed my life in more than one way - Nobuo Uematsu's timeless score, with it's clever variations on the main theme, was my inspiration to follow a career in music.  I've finished the game at least 20 times in almost as many years, and every time I look at the game in a different way. It is as relevant emotionally and politically now as it ever was. If you've never played it before, it's not too late. And if you have, then seeing it spruced up is a great experience. Could Squeenix have tried harder to make this a more unique experience? Absolutely. Is the DRM a nuisance? Some say it is - I haven't had a problem yet but I do fundamentally have a problem with the idea of DRM. So Squeenix definitely lose points for that. But it is great enough as it stands to be worth it anyway.

There's no doubt that this game is a classic, whether you like or not. But if it's actually held up all these years, that's a little more subjective. Expect blocky character models and low resolution (but still quite good looking, IMO) static backgrounds, and all the spelling and grammar errors from the original PC release are still here. However, the music has been replaced, the original MIDI soundtrack is now the same music used in the Playstation release, and the game overall has been optimized to run on new systems. The actual game mechanics and combat system are solid, and the story is also still good. If you've never played the game, don't come in expecting something that can stack up to a game released today in terms of graphical quality. If you can look past its age there's still a great game and plenty of time to be wasted in it, though. If you're looking for a nostalgia kick then it's definitely worth the price as well. The only detractor from what's overall a good game is the extra layer of DRM, requiring a Square Enix account, but considering it can be activated with your Steam account and ignored once you set it up the first time, it's hardly a hassle.

It's Final Fantasy VII...the first Final Fantasy that went 3D models from the start. The game itself is the same as it was when it was released, just with technical upgrades.  Essentially this is an updated copy of the FF7 PC release (which I own and have played through several times). The original used a very old version of Apple's QuickTime product, had a max resolution of 640x480 (double the PS1) but ran almost flawlessly. Also, since the code and save game setup work the same...well...you can edit the PC saved games with editors....you know...in case you don't want to spend a large portion of game time breeding magic riding chickens (Chocobos).  This version appears to also use QuickTime (I'm assuming a newer version). The resolution can go pretty high, although keep in mind while the graphics may scale, the models have not been touched. It still looks exactly the same. Keyboard controls can be customized to whatever keys you want, and there is joystick support as well. It also seems to run smoother than the old PC version, both in cutscene and actual play. Also the intro cutscene has been modified slightly since it includes the Square Enix logo instead of just the old Squaresoft brand.  Square Enix (formerly Square/Squaresoft) requires login/registration (sigh) to their site/account manager to register the game and provide extra features (just like Ewwbisoft) but also just like Ubisoft, you supposedly can play offline after the initial registration. Not sure yet whether or not that means FF7 can't be played under Steam's sharing setup, but since AC4 doesn't work, there's a chance this one won't either.

It's FINAL FANTASY FRIGGIN SEVEN. What the hell else do you need to know? It's still one of the best JRPGs of all time, and the game that would come to define an entire genre for over 10 years. Ignore whatever preconceptions you might have had about this game being overrated, or any kind of bad taste left in your mouth from the mostly-terrible Compilation of Final Fantasy VII. This game really is as good as you've heard, from the tight and expansive battle system, the highly customizable characters, the massive world filled with nooks and crannies to explore, and, of course, a great story. In Final Fantasy VII, you play the role of Cloud, an ex-SOLDIER working with a resistance company called AVALANCHE to take down his former employers, the Shin-Ra corporation. Along the way, you'll encounter giant rideable chickens, swords the size of your house and then some, more existential crises than you can wave a giant unwieldy sword at, and, of course, a whole pile of homoeroticism. Final Fantasy 7 â the first Playstation RPG I got my hands on back in the good old days. And even today I remember this one as a shiny gem, the best of the Final Fantasy series. But thats just my opinion soaked with a lot of nostalgia whenever I play it.  So, whats this game about? You are Cloud Strife, an EX-'Soldier',who used to work for Shinra, the world biggest corporation. Shinra's only interest is to suck as much 'Mako'-energy out of the planet as possible and use it to increase their power. So you end up with a group called 'Avalanche' to oppose them. Cloud does not seem to care much about this at first - his reason to 'join' Avalanche is referable to Tifa Lockhart, a childhood friend - but as you progress in the game, you will end up on a big journey facing a threat much bigger than Shinra.  The graphics are a little bit outdated, even the once beautiful backgrounds did not age to well, but the story and the amazing soundtrack do more than compensate for the graphics. You can also download some textures for the characters if you like to, which will make them look pretty impressive (Check the community-hub). Final Fantasy 7 can be played with a keyboard but I find it much more comfortable to play with a controller. The 360-pad works fine but I recommend a keybinder like JoytoKey (freeware) so you can use all of your buttons and bind everything to your needs.  Steam is actually selling it for 12.99â¬ and let me ensure you; totally worth it! It's extremely easy to put 100h+ into the game. First there is the main story, I think it took me about 60h back then. But there is much more to do(and discover) in between or at the end of the game including sidequests, hidden materias(magic) and items,breeding chocobos, some kind of RTS-battlefield and the Gold saucer; a huge theme park with attractions, minigames and an arena to test your skills.   My final verdict: If you are into RPG's Final Fantasy 7 is a must have. For everyone else, if you judge a game just by it's graphics you might get disappointed otherwise give it a try (battles can be fought in ATB or turn-based). The only downside is,that you have to register at Square-Enix to play the game. Final Fantasy VII (or Final Fantasy 7 for some people) is one of the most highly loved and rated games of all time, and while currently playing through it on Steam I have fallen in love with it all over again. The story was groundbreaking back in 1997 filled with memorable set-pieces and cutscenes, and while some scenes have lost their impact over the years (a certain scene comes to mind immediately ) the story still has some amazing plot twists and turns. The characters are fantastic for the most part, the only one I don't like being the main antagonist Sephiroth who really just has Mommy issues. Cloud is a very relatable character who goes through a lot of changes over the course of the game, questioning himself, his choices and even his own existance. Tifa is bubbly and always trying to make the situation right, Barrett is just downright hilarious, Red XIII is a mysterious creature who wants to return home, Cait Sith is a character who has more relevance to the plot than you may initially think, Aerith is a tragic story of Almost making it, Yuffie is a loli-trap who is actually a character with more to her than meets the eye, Vincent is badass and Cid is the greatest incarnation of the character in the entire Final Fantasy series. Let us not forget the addicting gameplay too, with an infinite amount of customization due to the Materia system, which assigned Spells/Commands/Summons etc. to characters.The graphics are outdated yes, but the world Final Fantasy VII is set in has an undeniable charm and atmosphere to it. Midgar is one of my favourite locations in any video game ever! Let us not forget the amazing soundtrack composed by Nobou Uematsu. Right from the get-go, the soundtrack of Final Fantasy VII is amazing. From the Opening~Bombing Mission to the classic One-Winged Angel, FFVII has one of the all-time best soundtracks to any game ever made. In fact, Final Fantasy VII would be my favourite game ever if it were not for the brilliant Tales of Xillia, but that's something I'll delve into if it ever gets a (very unlikely) release on Steam. FFVII is a classic that should not be missed or pre-judged on it's poor graphical presentation. This game changed the RPG genre forever and is one of the all time greats.  9/10

Welcome to the past! Sexy, sexy polygons.   Final Fantasy VII plays through your emotions by telling an intricate story about life, love, loss, confusion, revenge, and death. The simple (almost lego) character models provided a challenge that we don't really worry about these days: The characters had to express emotions using body language (no facial expressions). [Slight spoiler incoming] You can literally see the rage coursing through Barrett as he watches his hometown get destroyed. I find this form of expression refreshing compared to the perfectly rendered expressions in videogames these days. It makes it a bit difficult to empathize sometimes. But do your best- it's worth it!  Also, the polygons and twisty winding maps leave a LOT to the imagination- which is a good thing. Imagination is a form of thought that games have been slowly eliminating through our advances in detail. That's not to say I wouldn't want this game to be remade in beautiful stunning detail- I'm all for it! It would be like reading a book -then watching the movie and saying, 'Holy â¥â¥â¥â¥, they cast Ender PERFECTLY!!' -rather than skipping the book, watching the movie and thinking it had some cool concepts~  The real beauty in the game is a combination of the writer's inspiration and what they had to work with. The writers poured their hearts into making this game- they had no idea it would be such a hit. All they had were crummy PS1 graphics to work with, but they did what they could hoping people would like it. Nowadays, game devs have more than enough money and the writers are getting less and less passionate because of it. The Final Fantasy franchise has been going pretty strong and can still give me a good cry sometimes. But why was 7 such a hit? I'm thinking it was sincerity.  Something else that comes to mind is how the mini games weave into the standard gameplay like they ARE the standard gameplay. A player is expected to adapt on the fly~ One moment you're fighting in a turn based system, then suddenly you're on a motorcycle swatting baddies on either side! Don't forget snowboarding, chocobo races, and other golden saucer attractions!   ----------------------- SPOILER ALERT - personal feelings First time through (I'm talking 12 years old), I put all my time into Aeris. Her limit ability heals your entire party, so naturally she was my 'white mage'! I thought she'd be there forever- we dated and everything! I cried so many tears of sadness because of it. *sobs -----------------------  If you haven't played the game, I recommend it. The story is stellar; each character shares a bit of the spotlight. Some develop more than others, but they do ALL develop in some way. Read everything and explore everything. When you finish, go watch Advent Children and tell me what you think!

A classic game, but the PC port/update is...less than exemplary. There's the cloud saving system, for instance, but it uses your Square Enix account, not Steam's built-in Steam Cloud, and has gone down for significant periods a few times already. There's also the character booster, which is kind of a neat extra, though it depends on the cloud saving system. There are also achievements. Aside from these small value adds though, nothing seems to have been changed since the original PC port, including the inferior MIDI soundtrack from the PC version. The game can be modded to fix that and other things, but there's a catch; doing so will prevent you from using cloud saves (the system rejects any save made in a format it doesn't expect), character booster (which depends on the cloud saves), or achievements. So if you intend to mod the game to make it look better or to bring back the original soundtrack or whatever, you lose everything that Square Enix added and may as well look up the original PC port.  The game is good (of course, it's FFVII), but it sucks that Square Enix made such little effort on this new version and made it impossible to update yourself without losing the only things they did add. Another problem is that it doesn't allow you to map the D-pad on your controller to movement keys. It supports the analog stick, but it's almost unusable. I had to download Xpadder and map the D-pad to arrow keys for the controller to be a functional control scheme.  tl;dr: good game, bad port

If you've never played the game before and have heard about this game from other people, then this review will help you.  I've never played FF7 before, so I decided to buy the steam version to see all the hype!  And honestly, this game does not live up to all the hype people say it does. It's not a bad game, IT'S NOT BAD, it's good, but after hearing all the amazing things about this game, I was disappointed.  What the game does well: The gameplay is tight, you control 3 characters in your turned based style, each weapon has slots for items called materia. Materia give you access to spells and abillities, so you're gonna be hunting down a lot of these! The world itself is vast and there's A LOT to do. Once you get an airship the game becomes less linear and you're free to go where you wish. Before that, you'll be following the story mainly. The combat can get repetitive though, but it's an RPG so it's not surprising. There's a wide variety of characters to play as, but you have to keep Cloud in the party. The limit breaks look good too. Also, the music in this game is beautiful.  What the game doesn't do well: Some of the main cast are mediocre characters, very mediocre. HOWEVER, Vincent, Cid, Aeris, Yuffie and Tifa are awesome. On the other hand, you have Cloud-who is shallow, boring and just nothing like he's hyped up by fans of this game to be. He never takes charge of anything, his dialogue is usually just a generic response to someone else. His character development is kind of lame too. Cait Sith is hands down one of the worst, most annoying characters I've ever seen in a game. I don't know why Square decided to make Vincent optional, but have Cait Sith be in the main cast. The story itself is a wild goose chase to stop Sephiroth from destroying the world, but he's just a lame villain. Honestly, he has mommy issues, all he does is yammer on about her. His motivations are poorly explained too. The backstories for some of the main cast are lame too, I couldn't care for Cait, Barret or Red at all.  The animations for summons in this game take a fairly long time, which is frustrating. The idea of Sephiroth being an all power soldier goes down the drain at the end of the game too. I don't want to spoil too much.  I don't recommend this game tbh, it's really underwhelming.

This review contains no spoilers [I think], although you probably already know the big one.  Wow. Where do you even start with a review for a game like this? For some this is the greatest RPG ever made. For some this is probably the greatest game ever made. For some this is an overrated piece of garbage that has been getting far more attention than it deserved and just happened to come along at the right time.  I'm going to cop-out and say the answer is somewhere in the middle. Sorry.  I am not normally an RPG gamer. Whilst I like games with deep, involving stories, I generally don't have the patience for RPGs, preferring adventure games, whether point-and-click, action-adventure or even visual novels. My main dislikes of RPGs are the enormous time-sinks they can be - case in point I'm currently 55 hours into FFVII and still have some way to go - and the fact you can spend so much of this time grinding. I think roughly 15 of my 55 hours have been spent actively seeking out specific random encounters in the hope of finding certain rare items, levelling up or reaching higher Limit Breaks.  But I do have a weak spot for FFVII. Perhaps it's the blend of traditional hack'n'slash RPG story with a dystopian sci-fi twist. Perhaps it's the fact that the game itself is a deconstruction of then-cliched JRPG stereotypes [a fact that bypassed many because it was in fact their /first/ encounter with a JRPG]. Perhaps it just came along at the right time and was so massively popular that it was impossible to ignore. Maybe it's all of the above.  Just because something is popular doesn't mean it panders to the lowest common denominator. This is not an easy game. This is not a straight-forward game. Conversely, just because it's popular doesn't mean it's brilliant. The plot is at times difficult to follow [good luck finding the keystone on your first playthrough without either a guide or blind luck]. The game does require a lot of investment in order to get much reward.  I really do like this game. There you go. SIx paragraphs in and you get the opinion. I've bought FFVII 3 times - for the PS1, the PC [I wish I'd kept it - apparently it's quite collectable now] and now the Steam release. Whilst it isn't a game you can play for just half an hour here and there, it is something that I want to play through every few months just for the sheer experience.  Quite a lot of the negative reviews seem to focus on the fact that this game hasn't aged well. That isn't really the fault of the developers, who were struggling to produce a game that would run on the N64 before throwing in the towel and moving in with Sony. And no, it hasn't been remastered. You get the original PC release with a few tweaks here and there. If you want a remake, go and hassle Square-Enix. Yes, the backgrounds are blocky and the characters are made with laughably few polygons. There are mods out there [apparently] that change the character models, the music and suchlike. Use them if you want. For me, the appearance is part of the charm.  Things I like about FFVII: The battle mechanics: there are plenty of customisation options without ever feeling completely overwhelmed and the materia system works brilliantly. The story and the characters: when I first played FFVII back on release day [yes] I had never encountered such deep, complicated feelings in a video game. Frustration, anxiety, betrayal, the subject of mental illness, courage, determination, romance, shame, resentment, longing, hope and euphoria. Everything is here. You ask a player if they cried at the end of disc one. If they say no, they're probably lying [Actually, I was already blubbing thanks to Seto]. But that's the important thing. You wouldn't have such deep emotional involvement with a character if you'd only been introduced to them half-an-hour ago. The game is long and winding enough you get swept along for the ride and really feel for them all. Well, mostly. I never much cared for Cait Sith... You'll probably hate Yuffie if you somehow miss Wutai and her backstory. Oh, and the music is amazing.  Things I don't like about FFVII: The save system is a little annoying, but bear in mind this was made for a console and as such the save files had to be kept a reasonable size. It can take a while for the story to get going, but you'll be glad when it does. The massive J-turn when you are captured by Shina and wake up in the middle of the night to discover... well, you'll see... The 'super-deformed' look is a little baffling, perhaps only from a Western point of view. But I find it quite jarring when many of the in-game FMVs use much more detailed models.  Just a couple of points now. This Steam version is based on the PC version released in (I think) 1998. The original PC version fixed many of the faults of the PS1 version, including: Increase in resolution [character models only - backgrounds are still low-res], increase in number of saves [from 15 per card to 150] and many of the glaring translation errors have been fixed [except for the syntax error which lets many first timers get killed by the scorpion]. Unfortunately they replaced the PS1s tracker module music with horrible MIDI sounds. The Steam version takes this, replaces the MIDI with recordings of the PS1 music, allows you to customise the control layout, adds achievements and a few other bits and pieces.  So, in conclusion, if you like RPGs, buy it to see what all the fuss is about. If you're an avid gamer but have somehow never played it, buy it to see what all the fuss is about. Final fantasy VII is a classic, a game which deals with a lot of real world issues cleverly by mixing it into the fantasy world. It is a hybrid of fantasy and reality, with an industrialized/modern world meeting beasts and untamed lands. This game is however relatively dated (although some elements stand the test of time), but it is a must for any JRPG fan, as it offers traditional turn based combat, an intuitive magic (materia) system, lots of 'sidequests', a strong narrative and an open world to explore. This game captivated me when it was first released, and even to this day continues to do so. Final fantasy VII also uses humor throughout the game, and gives you 'options' with how to handle scenarios in the game, which impact the world, it is therefore a game you will find yourself playing again and again to revisit events and experience other paths (albeit all leads to same game ending). The cast of characters is colorful as well, and they have become iconic in their own rights. This game is designed with the 'traditional' JRPG elements of the time, something not often seen today, as such it is worth exploring for both fans and the untested alike. Overall this game is a full recommendation, its style may not be for all, but it is a relatively accessible and enjoyable gaming experience and it is priced appropriately, giving you a substantial amount of game (30+ hours easily).

One of the most memorable JRPGs ever that really made weebs the weebs today.  These days I think people only really play it for nostalgia's sake.  ..and because of the announcement of the upcoming remake.    Though much of the game's mechanics are modernly outdated, like most of the mini-games and some of the UI that are a little odd & time consuming to get around, it's got an extremely engaging story and non-linear exploration with satisfying rewards to back it up. As you progress your ways of exploration vastly improve and it's a rewarding experience when those points are reached.   During a battle the camera is set by default to cinematically move around. When you're choosing a target after selecting an attack, item, or whatever to use on and the camera's still moving it can be a little bit of a nuisance to try and set the cursor to your desired target. It can be a bit time consuming on making sure you've selected the right target in this case especially if the camera's still moving around because an attack is in progress. It doesn't help that the game functions on an active time battle mechanic so if you take too long deciding a target the enemy may make a move before you make a selection. The cinematic camera viewing can be toggled to sit still to look like previous Final Fantasy games.  Some of the maps can be a little confusing to get around where the blame is on the map design. You and other 3D NPCs are basically walking in front of either a still image or a looping video. When trying to go through doorways, roads that curve oddly, or whatever the like it can be extremely confusing to get around and find out where exactly you can set foot on the map.  The graphics are blatantly outdated, maybe even for 1997, but I think there's a real big charm to that.  The most in-depth part about this game regarding the actual main gameplay is the Materia system where each piece of Materia either casts a spell, summons, support other Materia, etc. which almost all will take the biggest roles in battles.  For better or worse the story, characters, music, and the world of FF7 is really what makes this entire game highly unique which got me hooked up until it's kind of lame ending.

This is a very basic overview of FF7 and is meant for those people looking to play the game for the first time. I tried to be unbiased because there are plenty of reviews that will tell you the game is the best ever, ermagerd! You gotta play it!!  Final Fantasy 7 is very story driven, but does not have any voice acting. You have to read to experience the story and skipping through dialog could mean that you miss out of important story details. Graphics are very outdated as this game is about 20 years old. Battle-System is turned based; turned based means you will need to wait for your action bar to fill before you can give your characters commands to attack or use magic. This might sound daunting for those who have never played a turn-based battle system, but it takes around 2 seconds for the bar to fill. Turn based is important for the game because you do have a lot of options for magic and attacks once you get deeper into the game. Character inventory is limited to a weapon slot, armor slot, and accessory slot, but this limitation works well for the game's design. Game starts out a bit slow, but then drastically picks up towards the middle through till the end and has many hours of side content. The game isn't very challenging as long as you put time into leveling your characters a bit before each boss fight. I recommend playing with a game guide so that you can get the full experience as there is a lot of side story and side content that could be easily missed.   This game remains in my top three all time favorites and will probably always be there as well. The story is incredible and could be a stand alone book by itself. Final Fantasy 7 is best played when you are looking to play something to immerse yourself in. The game is very rewarding and could very easily leave you wanting more. Luckily unlike other games, there are other media content available to further the story after you have beaten the game. I definitely recommend doing a play through even if just for the basic story if you are planning on playing the remake that has been announced. I have recommended that game many times to friends and even have bought steam copies for a few because I firmly believe in this game and its story.  10/10 would recommend

This is a rerelease of an old game so first I will cover the differences between this version and the original before entering an opinion about the original product.   If you have played the game before you will immediately notice the graphical difference. The textures have all been cleaned up and smoothed out. The first product of this is what I call 'Lego Face' where everyone has what looks like painted on faces and many of the characters are stuck with permanent 'O' mouths which are humorous. The second and larger problem is the screen backgrounds (Non-textured/interactive areas) have not been touched at all and have simply been stretched to fit the screen so they are horribly pixelated. Some screens are so bad it is hard to make out what the scenery is supposed to be and the characters look out of place. For this reason I have to fail the graphics even after giving a pass on the PSX-era graphics obviously.   As for the actual game it is of course a classic haralded for bringing this style of RPG back to the mainstream market. The music compositions as well as the character development and story progression have been raved about for decades. That being said, there is a nostalgia factor with most people that played the game during the PSX days and the game may not have aged well for new audiences. First the game is buggy...to the point there are several Save-File-Corrupting bugs that no rerelease version has bothered to fix. As far as the gameplay difficulty is set to 'Idiot Proof'. To illustrate this there is a point in the game where on the screen before a major boss battle you are, in plain sight, given a chest containing an item that renders you invinicible in that boss battle and this is no isolated incident. You will find guides for the game that severely limit what upgrades and items you can use in an attempt to create difficulty.   At the time of it's release I can tell you the amount of character development was great. We grow with some characters and we start to see others in a different light. Sure the story was so-so and played up many tropes and cliche situations but at the time everything out was so flat that it stood out. I have to say it does feel dated though. Taking off the nostalgia glasses I really see the characters different than I did as a pre-teen and all of the 'deep' commentary about brooding angst, capitalism, religion, and the environment is really just eye-roll worthy.   All of that being said, when it is on sale (I got for $3 at the time of my purchase) it is worth it to play either simply for the nostalgia or to see where games came from to see where they got today.

They just didn't appeal to me anymore. It wasn't until the fall of 97, when I, a bright-eyed youngster just starting the 5th grade, played FFVII for the first time. I came in with no real expectations and thus, was not ready for the impact it'd have on my young, impressionable mind.  I fell in love, almost immediately. This was the game I had been waiting to play my entire life. To say I was obsessed was an understatement. All I wanted to talk about at school with my buddies was 'FFVII this and FFVII that!' I drew pictures of Cloud and Barrett all over my notebooks, I spent hours pouring over all the pictures in the strategy guide and I had the time of my life. This game made me laugh (Cloud in drag lol), it made me cry (Aerith.. RIP) and I knew from that moment, that I was a gamer for life.  It's since been 16 years and no other game has been quite as important to me. Final Fantasy Tactics is perhaps my favorite game in the series and Final Fantasy X had the best battle and leveling up system, but neither can touch what VII means to me. I've played other games over the years, games that I obsessed over as well.. from Super Mario World to the Last of Us, I've had a long time to play many games.. but no other game will ever touch Final Fantasy VII. To see it still be so popular makes me happy and I really hope that one day, we have a genuine remake so that a new generation of gamers can fall in love with these characters as I did.

I really enjoyed this game as a youth, and then as I got older I grew apart from turn based RPGs. I was really suprised to find that I not only still enjoyed this game, but absolutely loved it years later. What stands the test of time is the characters and world that the game so carefully builds as you play. You want the good guys to win and you want the bad guys to lose. Every character you gain feels like they have a good reason to be there. I often found I wanted to bring more characters along than my party would allow.   That materia system is great and ties into the world's background really well. Its very simple and versatile, and leaves you carefully considering what kind of equipment you would like to equip to plan for the proper amount of slots.  While I say that I enjoy the translation this game, it is not without its issues. There are a few times where plot points are not explained entirely well, and it can be hard to keep track of exactly 'who' is talking. This is perhaps why the game has a reputation for being 'deep' or 'artistic' in its writing, because it leaves much to the players interpretation.   In the end, I would reccomend this game to anyone who likes turn based RPGs or JRPGS. To anyone who once enjoyed this and thought it would not hold up, I would reccomend you give it another go, because I ended falling in love with it all over again.   Happy Gaming

I bought Final Fantasy VII more on a whim than anything. I'd heard it was a good game and had even heard that it was the best. I had the money, bought it, played an hour or 2 and then stopped for a long time. I started it back up again a little while back and I am glad I did.  Gameplay: 8/10 If you don't know how Final Fantasy works then you need a heavy dose of internet. This game holds the standard turn-based combat, however there is one difference I've noticed. This game can be switched into a real-time non-stop combat sort of deal. I don't mean being able to do whatever but rather the game doesn't stop for you. It may seem small but I am very glad this was a feature. In this game, the combat doesn't stop to let you think. If the enemy is faster than you, they'll attack more and if you take too long to think, they'll keep wailing on you. There are several times when I would be defeated because my character was killed before they could attack and I was never too angry. It was annoying on occasion, especially when an enemy turned me to stone or used that stupid FROG SONG but for the most part I could live with it. You level up by winning battles and so on. You also have Materia in this game which is basically something you can equip into your weapons and armor to give skills and boosts. A Cure Materia lets that character use Cure and if you link that with an All Materia then they can cast Cure on the entire party! The Materia allows for a lot of customizability in this game. You don't have to force Aeris into being a cleric (although character stats may influence things). I equipped Cure on all of my main party (Cloud, Tifa, Barret) and it worked out splendidly. The game makes a point that when certain Materia is equipped, certain stats are raised and lowered, however I never actually found this to affect anything. This game may also occasionally throw a special minigame sort of thing at you like the Chocobo Races later on and they're cool and all but the game has a habit of saying things like 'Use [Switch] to do this' or something like that and it refers to whatever key that command is bound to and it gets annoying because some are rarely used. Combat has Ultimate attacks as well which are very powerful attacks that vary depending on which one you've earned, although they tend to be a nuisance a lot of the time. A bar fills when you get hit and when it peaks you can use any Ultimate of the level you have equipped, but you can't do a regular attack until you use it. This caused me a lot of frustration when I'm saving my Ultimate for a boss but don't have the MP to keep using spells.  Story: 9/10 Story is a tad cliche with the 'save the world' sort of thing, but it does so very well. Your character (I will call him Cloud) is an ex-SOLDIER who is helping AVALANCHE take down the Shinra corporation because they're killing the planet. He helps destroy a factory and leaves saying he doesn't care about the world. After some convincing he tries to be cool guy and helps save the world. The game starts off with you in Midgard, then after events you start exploring to save the world. You meet some interesting characters with some pretty good backstories. Cloud wants revenge on Sephiroth, Tifa is helping Cloud, Barrett wants to protect his little girl and many more. They're told much better in game, trust me. You travel around and fight monsters and travel some more. The traveling is where I feel the game lacks. A bit later in the game I found myself lost. I couldn't figure out where to go and I'm not sure if I missed key dialogue or what but there were times I found the way forward on accident. SPOILER ALERT! Later in the game you go to find Sephiroth. Where is he? Well I traveled all the way north to a fossil village and somebody there answered my question. He went through there to find the Temple of the Ancients which is on the exact opposite side of the world. Wait what?  Graphics: 7/10 I shouldn't bag on it too much because it was originally PS1 but I don't think they're the best and some CGI cutscenes weren't very well done in my opinion.  Sense of Progression: 7/10 This may be a bit of my personal getting lost, but any progress seemed lackluster as sometimes bosses would appear out of nowhere. I'm leaving a place, use a door and then BOOM! Wall demon? I'm not sure if I missed some context but... I never truly felt like I progressed at most times as I fought so much trying to find the objective I didn't know the location of that I would one-shot most normal enemies and bosses stopped being difficult.  Enemies: 8/10 Varied and special. Some had resistances, some used spells. Then there's the frogs... I don't like the frogs.  Length: 10/10 36 hours and only completed the first disc. I'm in for a long ride.  Overall: 8/10 I had to speed this up due to Steam review character limits but I do say this game is good. I can see why a lot of people praise it so and I would recommend it to anyone with the money if it's $20 or less.

This was my very first RPG back in 1997 on the PS1. I fell in Love with RPGs after this game and, well, have played and beaten every possible version/port/sequel/prequel (Excluding the cell phone game that never made it to the US) associated with FF7. When I found out there was a PC version back in 2003 I jumped on it immediately. Despite the Chocobo racing bug, despite the horrible midi music, and despite everyone aside from the main playable characters unable to close their mouths I still loved the PC version. Then the Graphic mods came out. Needless to say I was playing this game non-stop again. I was a bit confused when Steam said they had a version with extra features cause I thought it was just the PC port with maybe the bugs fixed. I was glad to see achievements added and better then the one that came directly from SE's re-release.  FF7 redefined RPGs and did a fantastic job at setting the bar. The story is very in depth and the twists you encounter are fantastic. SE (then Squaresoft) made very risky and Bold decisions while making this game. The story aside the gameplay is amazing. The Materia system makes for easy customization of characters and skills while still limiting the amount of skills you can use, but completely interchangeable. FF7 was probably the first FInal Fantasy game that really required inventory management and strategy on how you customized your characters. Do you go with the super powerful weapon with 2 non-linked materia slots or do you go with the okay weapon with 8 linked materia slots? Do you equip the added effect materia with bio on your weapon to add poison to your attack or your armor to protect you from poison? DO you use the ALL materia with your Cure or your Fire? DO I use this weapon that give me more slots but no materia exp or not? Choices that really effect HOW you play.  The mini games are fun as well and not just 1 time events. The Gold Saucer lets you go back and replay any mini game you have already done at least once in the main story. Take Road Rash, Cool Boarders, underwater submarine battles, and 'Horseback Racing' (Done on Chocobos) and put them into FF7 and you can spend countless hours just messing around.  FF7 is challenging and very rewarding with tons of side-quests that give you a good payoff but also enrich the story and characters. Not to mention multiple optional bosses, secret gear, hidden/optional characters. There is so much to be done in FF7 you wont be disappointed.  Thankfully the things I don't like about this port you don't have to do or use.  The Character booster is a bit of a let down. Instead of just maxing out your level it only increases your HP, MP and Gil to the 'max' and dummies down the enemy's stats. I would have rather just seen it increase my character's level to 99. Using it early on in the game makes limit breaks impossible to ever obtain and just eliminates the 'getting to know how to play' stage where you developed strategy. Plus once you use it there is NO going back. So if you are stuck on a boss and just wanna get a quick boost to beat it then go back to playing normally you can't you are stuck with the weaker enemies and constant leveling that just becomes un-important. I would have rather seen a character editor then a booster. But luckily you don't have to use it, so it's a moot point.  The only other thing I would haveliked to see would be a New Game+ option.  In all FF7 is still a FANTASTIC rpg and although the graphics are.... well... blocky... the game has aged very very well.  20/10  Plus play this before the Remake comes out so you can fully enjoy the Remake!

In 1997, a JRPG like no other took the world by storm and introduced the West to a whole new type of video game. It was upbeat, clever, and full of grand adventure. It was dark, heartbreaking, and full of moments of despair as well as triumph. It was massive, containing a world that took at least seventy hours, if not even more, to fully explore. It was also concise, gathering nine unique, broken but hopeful heroes in a quest to defeat a near unstoppable madman, all ten of whom have since become icons in gaming worldwide. And through it all, a soaring musical score gave them all identity, personality, and relatability in a game with no spoken words.  This game...was Final Fantasy VII.  Like the first six Final Fantasies before it, FFVII is a standalone title with its own story, characters, and universe. As such, you can jump right in without missing anything. In this installment, you take up the massive sword of Cloud Strife, a sullen yet determined young man with more to his initial demeanor than meets the eye. In your very first mission, you join a gang of eco terrorists named AVALANCHE and blow up a city power plant, defying the corrupt energy company that controls most of the planet, but costing untold innocent lives in the process. But soon events spiral beyond your control, and it's up to you to save the planet alongside the brittle AVALANCHE leader Barret, a beautiful flower girl named Aerith, and Tifa, the only friend you have left from your old life...  FFVII plays like most old school JRPGs, with your party wandering a massive world map and encountering monsters and enemies as you go. The combat is turn based, wherein you and your opponents attack in turns with different moves, ranging from attacks with your weapons to magical spells to summoning all manner of creatures and warriors to inflict massive amounts of damage. Each ability you can use is equipped with a gemstone called a Materia, which you can level up for more powerful results by continuously fighting with it equipped. Practicing Materia combinations can result in some incredible strategies, so experiment until you find the combos that work best for you.  Newcomers not used to JRPGs or retro gaming may not immediately click with a game that came out back in 1997. Their initial response is understandable, given that video games and the technology used to make them were very different back then. Personal feelings and the fanbase's nostalgia aside, the character models for the world map and non combat events are very simple and low detail, with their quality improving during battles and cinematic cutscenes. This is also a localized game originally from Japan, and some things tend to get lost in translation. The Steam version is apparently much better than the original Playstation release, but there are occasional odd moments in dialogue. As stated above, none of this dialogue is spoken, which means you're reading everything the characters say via word bubbles.   The plot can be a little hard to follow if not paid complete attention to, and the lore is pretty expansive. Certain moments feel a little jumbled (and one section slightly distasteful), and not everything is always made entirely clear. It can be a real grind to, well, grind up experience for the Materia you need to kill the more powerful bosses, especially towards the end of the game.  But the biggest potential issue that even diehard fans will admit to?  Minigames.  Minigames EVERYWHERE.  However, these gameplay mechanics and designs, these flaws, should not be used as an excuse to not give this game a good ten to twenty hours before quitting. There is a reason so many Final Fantasy fans will declare this game the best of the series and/or their personal favorite, and why Square Enix has finally caved to the years of demands for a full remake on newer consoles. The story here is one of the most powerful you will ever experience, and the extra lengths you go to become stronger make the end battles you fight all the more sweeter to win. Your party almost becomes a little family to you, friends you never thought you'd make. You'll laugh. You'll cry. You'll clench your fist in rage and pump it in the air in triumph.  Because I guarantee that once you've begun Final Fantasy VII, 'there ain't no gettin' off this train!'  9/10

It's hard to make an unbiased review of a game that you enjoyed with your entire family when the game was released, but here it goes:  Music: The soundtrack is phenomenal and provides great ambiance for the various situations you find yourself in. I really love most of Uematsu's work anyway, but this soundtrack is definitely in my top two!  Story: The main storyline is great. Even though it does not always provide the best character development, the game provides some interesting side quests to fill in the blanks. There are a lot of great moments where the characters really come to life despite their polygonal forms.  Battle: The PC version maintained all of the same mechanics as the PS1 version. The turn-based fighting can be tedious, especially in the beginning when you have no helpful materia. It is really great that you can be powerful without hours and hours of grinding up to level 100. I think I beat the game at level 38 at my lowest.  Mini-games: Sometimes I get so consumed by the mini-games, I spend hours playing and run out of money. I also love how Squaresoft smoothly incorporated some of the mini-games into the main storyline.  Overall: 9.75/10 - I can't wait to see how the HD remake enhances this already fantastic game!
